text: Is multi-factor authentication required for accessing sensitive systems?
expected_answer: Yes, MFA is required for all remote access and sensitive data systems, enforced through our identity management system. Authentication methods include hardware tokens, mobile authenticator apps, and SMS codes.

text: Is an incident response plan documented and maintained?
expected_answer: Yes, we maintain a comprehensive incident response plan with defined roles, responsibilities, procedures, incident classification, escalation procedures, and communication protocols. The plan is reviewed annually and team members receive training.

text: Is antivirus/antimalware software deployed on all endpoints?
expected_answer: Yes, enterprise antivirus is deployed on all workstations and servers with automatic daily definition updates, weekly full scans, enforced real-time protection, and user-disabled prevention.

text: How does the organization manage and monitor privileged access across systems?
expected_answer: Privileged access follows least privilege principles with manager-approved requests. Access is reviewed quarterly and during role changes. All privileged activities are logged and monitored in real-time with monthly audits. Alerts trigger for unusual behavior, and admin sessions are recorded and retained for 90 days.

text: What encryption controls are in place to protect data throughout its lifecycle?
expected_answer: Data is classified (public, internal, confidential, restricted) with appropriate handling requirements. All network transmission uses TLS 1.2+ or IPSec VPN. Data at rest is protected through database encryption, full-disk encryption on file servers, and BitLocker on endpoints. Keys are managed through a centralized system.

text: What processes ensure vulnerabilities are identified and remediated in a timely manner?
expected_answer: Monthly vulnerability scans are performed on production systems and weekly on internet-facing systems. Critical patches are applied within 7 days, high-severity within 30 days. Annual third-party penetration tests cover external, internal, and application security. Findings are tracked in a vulnerability management system with severity-based due dates, monthly progress reviews, and verification scans.
